text: yeah the way I think about attention is
really as a problem of routing routing
signals so actually we know a lot about
how signals come in through your sensory
apparatus through your ears and your
eyes uh we know an awful lot about how
the retina Works how the ca Works uh we
understand how the signals travel up and
eventually they percolate up to the
cortex in the case of sound they
percolate up to the auditory cortex and
we know a lot about uh a fair amount
about how they look once they uh get
there and after that we kind of lose
track of them and we can't really pick
up the signal until they're coming out
the other end we know a lot about
Movement we we understand an awful lot
about what happens when a nerve impulse
gets to a muscle and how muscles
contract that's been pretty well
understood for 50 years or something
even more than that so where we really
lose track of them is when they uh enter
into the early parts of the sensory
cortex and when they're and we pick them
up again sort of on the on the other
side and so attention is one of the ways
in which signals uh can find their
destination if you like so think about
it in terms of a really specific uh
problem imagine that I ask you to raise
your right hand when I say go okay so I
say go you raise your right hand go
raise your right right hand now let's
change it uh and I say go raise your
left hand go raise your left hand so
somehow the same signal coming in
through your ear is producing different
activity at the other end somehow the
signal on the sensory side had to be
routed to either the muscles of your
right hand or the muscles of your left
hand now attention is a special case of
that kind of General routing problem
that the brain faces all the time
because when you attend to let let's say
your uh sounds rather than your visual
input or when you attend to one
particular auditory input out of uh many
what you're doing is you're you're
selecting some subset of the inputs in
this case coming in uh to your ears and
and subjecting them to further
processing and you're you're taking
those signals and routing them
Downstream and doing stuff with them how
that routing happens that's the aspect
of attention that uh my lab focuses on
so so the basic setup for the problem
that I'm interested in is this imagine
that you're at a cocktail party there
are a bunch of conversations going on
and you're talking to someone but
there's all this distracting stuff going
on the sidelines you can make a choice
you can either focus on the person
you're talking to and ignore the rest or
as often happens you find that the
conversation that you're engaged in is
not as interesting and uh-huh uh-huh oh
really H summer okay and you start
focusing on the this conversation on the
right your ability to focus in on this
conversation while ignoring that
conversation that is sort of the
challenge understanding how we do that
is the challenge of of my research and
that that problem actually has two
separate aspects so there's one aspect
of that problem that is really a problem
of computation it's it's a problem that
is a challenge to basically any computer
namely uh we have a whole bunch of
different sounds and from a bunch of
different sources and they're
superimposed at the level of the ears
and somehow they're they're added
together and to us it's typically pretty
effortless for us to separate out those
different threads of the
conversation uh but actually that's a
surprisingly difficult task so uh
computers maybe 10 years ago already
were getting pretty good at doing uh
speech recognition and in in uh
controlled situations and quiet rooms
computers were actually pretty good at
recognizing even uh random speakers but
when people uh actually started
deploying these in real world settings
where there's traffic noise and whatnot
the computer algorithms broke down
completely and it was sort of surprising
at first because that's the aspect that
we as humans seem to have uh not much
trouble with at all so the the uh
ability to take take apart the different
components of an auditory scene that's
what we've evolved for hundreds of
millions of years to do really well um
so that's one aspect of attention
there's almost this sort of um uh aspect
of it that happens before we're even
aware of it where the auditory scene is
broken down into the components the the
other aspect which is uh the one that
we're sort of more consciously aware of
is the one where out of the many
components of this conversation we or of
this auditory we select one and that's
the one we focus in on right so at this
hypothetical cocktail party uh we have
the choice of focusing on either the
conversation we're engaged in or this
one or that one
